question: A tree is a hierarchical data structure used to represent relationships between elements.
In a General Tree, each node can have at most two children.
In a Binary Tree, each node can have at most two children.
A Binary Search Tree (BST) follows the rule that the right child contains smaller values than the parent.
A Binary Search Tree (BST) allows efficient searching and sorting operations.
Pre-Order Traversal visits the left child before the root.
In-Order Traversal results in nodes being visited in sorted order for a Binary Search Tree.
Post-Order Traversal follows the sequence Left → Right → Root.
Level-Order Traversal visits nodes level by level from top to bottom.
If a Binary Tree has N nodes, it always has N edges.
A Binary Tree is a type of Graph.
A Full Binary Tree is a tree where every node has either 0 or 2 children.
A Complete Binary Tree is a tree where every level is completely filled except possibly the last level.
A Heap is a special type of Binary Tree used in priority queues.
Post-Order Traversal is commonly used in expression evaluation.
Binary Search Trees store duplicate values in both left and right subtrees.
A Binary Search Tree with a single node has a height of 1.
A tree with only one node is called a Singleton Tree.
Tree traversal can only be done using recursive methods.
A tree with N nodes will always have N-1 edges.
